newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy Welfare needs balance, not less cash-Micheli.
newsitem.headline: Italy Welfare needs balance, not less cash-Micheli.

text.p: Italy's welfare state needs rebalancing but without cutting overall social spending as a percentage of gross domestic product, cabinet secretary Enrico Micheli said.

"Our aim is to rebalance social welfare expenditure logically without reducing the percentage of GDP but by working on an internal balancing out of spending," he told a joint social affairs commission of the lower house of parliament.

Micheli said that despite substantial welfare improvements in recent years, the system "needs further rebalancing from 1998," particularly with the full introduction over time of a contribution-based system.
Micheli noted that social spending in Italy "is on the whole not dissimilar from that of other European countries." But there was a "major imbalance in the structure."
He said that in Italy 61.5 percent of social spending went on pensions and 18.4 percent on social welfare, against a European Union average of 45.3 percent and 31.9 percent repectively.
He noted that according to World Bank data, "in the year 2000 Italy will have the highest dependency ratio (of people drawing pensions against people in active employment) among G-7 nations.
"In 50 years, the dependency ratio in Italy will be equal to 60 percent compared with an average 46.5 percent in other G-7 countries," he added.
